script.speaker: David
script.text: Welcome to the Come Follow Me Podcast by Gospel Study App. I'm David.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: And I'm Sarah.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Sarah, let's dive right into something that has intrigued me about Genesis 5. It's mostly this genealogy from Adam to Noah, a list of names and ages, but then we hit verse 24: 'And Enoch walked with God: and he was not; for God took him.' Why just that cryptic line about Enoch amid all the others? What profound truth is hidden there?

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: David, that's the perfect opening. Genesis 5 leaves us hanging, but Moses 6 unveils Enoch's full story—a reluctant prophet who transforms into a mighty leader. It's a reminder that behind every name in those lists are lives of divine purpose.

script.speaker: David
script.text: I'm intrigued. Tell me more about how Moses 6 reveals what Genesis conceals.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: In Moses 6:26–36, we see Enoch's call. He says to the Lord, 'Why is it that I have found favor in thy sight, and am but a lad, and all the people hate me?' He feels inadequate, like a child among giants. Yet God sees potential where Enoch sees weakness.

script.speaker: David
script.text: That resonates deeply. It sets up this tension—God calling the unlikely. How does Enoch respond?

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: God reassures him: 'As I live, even so will I come in the midst of the earth and among my people' (Moses 6:30). Then in verse 32, 'Go forth and do as I have commanded thee, and no man shall pierce thee.' It's divine empowerment despite human frailty.

script.speaker: David
script.text: What's fascinating is viewing this from multiple angles. From Enoch's perspective, it's overwhelming insecurity. From God's view, it's untapped strength. How does that shift our understanding of prophetic calls?

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Exactly. It mirrors how prophets across dispensations felt. Think of Moses in Exodus 4:10, 'I am slow of speech.' Or Jeremiah 1:6, 'I am a child.' Even Nephi in 2 Nephi 33:2 struggles with words. God consistently calls the hesitant and qualifies them.

script.speaker: David
script.text: That's a profound pattern. Let's trace it further. Enoch's story isn't isolated—it's part of Adam's lineage teaching gospel truths.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Yes, Moses 6 shows Satan's great dominion early on (verse 15), but righteous parents teach 'the ways of God' (verse 21). This leads to Enoch's era, where he builds Zion, a city that walks with God—literally fulfilling that Genesis phrase.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Walks with God. So the pattern builds across generations. What happens next in Enoch's ministry?

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: After his call, verses 37–47 describe God's support. Enoch sees visions, the earth mourns, and he preaches repentance. Notice verse 34: the youth theme 'Walk with Me' comes from here—God inviting Enoch to abide in His presence.

script.speaker: David
script.text: I love how that invitation reflects divine consistency. Now, shifting perspectives: from ancient reader to modern disciple, how does Enoch model overcoming sin's effects?

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Moses 6:26–36 details sin blinding eyes, dulling ears, stiffening hearts. Enoch overcomes through humility and faith. God blesses him with opened eyes—'eyes to see' (verse 35), even clay symbolizing restoration.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Clay on eyes—powerful symbol. Let's explore historical context. What was Enoch's world like archaeologically or culturally?

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Enoch lived in a time of widespread wickedness, post-flood precursors. Ancient traditions, like those in the Book of Giants from Dead Sea Scrolls, portray giants and chaos, aligning with Moses 6's 'giants upon the face of the earth' reflects in broader Enoch literature, but our text focuses on covenant restoration.

script.speaker: David
script.text: That cultural backdrop makes Enoch's rise remarkable. No wonder he felt like a 'lad.' How does God resolve Enoch's doubts?

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: In verses 36–37, God raises a Seer—Enoch himself. 'Open thy mouth,' God commands, and Enoch speaks powerfully. It's qualification through priesthood power.

script.speaker: David
script.text: That resolves the opening mystery. The cryptic Genesis line points to Zion's translation. But there's more—gospel doctrines emerge.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Precisely. Moses 6:48–68 reveals Adam learning redemption: faith in Jesus Christ, repentance, baptism by water and Spirit. Verse 59: 'born of the Spirit' and water symbolize rebirth.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Adam's question in verse 53: 'How to be born of the Spirit?' The Lord's answer is our first baptismal sermon.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Yes! 'Except ye are born again ye cannot be saved' (verse 59). This doctrine 'was in the beginning [and] shall be in the end' (verse 7). Eternal pattern.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Remarkable connection. Hidden links: hearts and ears in verse 27—'their hearts have waxed hard, and their ears are dull of hearing.'

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Those symbols reflect spiritual blindness. Just as Jesus heals blind men with clay (John 9), God restores Enoch's sight, pointing to the Savior.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Profound typology. And water in verses 59–60 foreshadows temple ordinances.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Absolutely. Baptism as being born again ties to covenants in the plan of salvation—agency, atonement, exaltation.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Let's uncover more cross-references. This priesthood and gospel link to Adam's family book of remembrance.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Moses 6:46 mentions it—early record-keeping. Connects to Doctrine and Covenants 128:24 on welding links, ancient to modern.

script.speaker: David
script.text: That's significant. Parents commanded: 'Teach these things freely unto your children' (verse 58). Links to Mosiah 4:14–15.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Yes, and D&C 68:25–28, 93:40–50. Eternal parental duty amid Satan's opposition.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Pattern across dispensations: Adam to Enoch to us.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Now modern application: Elder Bednar's 'Walk with Me' talk reflects Moses 6:34. It's about abiding in Christ daily.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Elder Soares shares similar feelings of inadequacy when called. Like Enoch.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Precisely. When we feel overwhelmed, remember God's words: 'Walk with me' (Moses 6:34). He empowers.

script.speaker: David
script.text: What strikes me is the continuity. Enoch's Zion translated—our stakes as modern Zion.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Yes, building holy communities today. Overcoming sin's blindness through covenants.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Another layer: JST context in Moses expands Genesis, showing restoration's role.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Hebrew 'Enoch' means dedicated—fitting for one who walks with God. 'Halak' implies intimate companionship.

script.speaker: David
script.text: That deepens it. Apparent contradiction: long lives in Genesis 5, yet sin dominates. Resolution in gospel teaching.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Right—righteous line preserves truth. Enoch sees 'God weeping' in Moses 7, but here preparation.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Multi-perspective: from Adam's fall to Enoch's triumph.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: And forward to our day. President Nelson teaches eternal progression mirrors this.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Hidden connection: Ether 12:27 on weakness to strength, like Enoch.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Moroni reflects it. Pattern perfected.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Symbols converge: water, Spirit, rebirth—plan of salvation core.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Tying premortal to postmortal through ordinances.

script.speaker: David
script.text: For today: when called to serve, embrace Enoch's path.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Journal experiences like the book of remembrance. Teach children these truths.

script.speaker: David
script.text: That's meaningful. Any overlooked detail?

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Verse 52: order of ordinances—faith, repentance, baptism, Holy Ghost. Foundation from beginning.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Overlooked gem. Changes everything.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: It does. Reveals God's unchanging plan.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Sarah, this transforms Genesis 5 from list to legacy.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Agreed. Every name matters.

script.speaker: David
script.text: As we close, invitation: study Moses 6, identify your 'walk with God' moments.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Feel God's call despite weaknesses. Teach your family these eternal truths.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Walk with Him daily. Thanks, Sarah.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: My pleasure, David. Until next time.
